step_by_step_thinking: The patient presents with jaundice, pruritus, elevated urinary bilirubin, and low urobilinogen. Elevated urinary bilirubin indicates conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, as unconjugated bilirubin is not excreted in urine. Low urobilinogen suggests impaired bile excretion, as urobilinogen is derived from intestinal bacterial breakdown of bilirubin. Defective hepatic bile excretion (D) leads to conjugated bilirubin accumulation, bilirubinuria, and reduced urobilinogen. Absent UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (A) causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which does not result in urinary bilirubin. Increased hemoglobin breakdown (B) and intestinal reabsorption (C) are unrelated to the findings.
